creditline: Gift of Kenneth C. Jacobson, Class of 1970
inscribed:
Printed on mount above image, center: Size of Original Phtoograph, 32 by 22. — From Nature.

Titled on mount beneath print, center: When the Day’s Work is Done.

Printed on mount below image, overall: French Honours to English Art. / (From the Tunbridge Wells Courier, / September 13th, 1878.) / “One of the much coveted gold medals / of the French Universal Exhibition is to come / to Tunbridge Wells. This is an honour to the / town as well as to the fortunate recipient. This / great prize has been awarded to Mr. H. P. / ROBINSON, the well-known photographer, of the / Great Hall Studio. T his is we believe the only / medal of the kind awarded to photographers. / The gold medals, we hear, have been very / sparingly distributed, and only for exceptional / merit. The other awards of gold medals to / English artists are to Mr. G. F. Watts, R.A., / and Mr. Alma-Tadema, A.R.A. Mr. ROBINSON / has taken his honours in good company.”

makers.displaydate: 1830–1901; born Ludlow, England; died Tunbridge Wells, England
makers.displaymaker: Henry Peach Robinson, 1830–1901; born Ludlow, England; died Tunbridge Wells, England

texts.textentryhtml: Robinson brought the art of photography into sync with British Academic painting of his time through popular, large-scale compositions such as When the Day's Work is Done. He used five negatives to create this unique combination print-note the appearance of dark "seams" wherever two negatives meet, as at the edge of the carpet in the foreground. Each negative contributes a distinct allegorical or narrative note. Winter vegetables in the foreground suggest the pious couple's agrarian labors, while the glimpse of town through the window hints at their distance from worldly affairs. Thanks to Robinson's printing technique, every detail appears in sharp focus, ready to be drawn into service in the homiletic reading prompted by the picture's title.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1991," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 51, no. 1 (1992): p. 22-78.
